definition: to oppose each other with equal harshness (idiom); tit for tat/measure for measure
needle/pin/injection/stitch/CL:根[gen1],支[zhi1]
point of a spear/edge of a tool/vanguard/forward (in sports team)
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
surname Xiang
right/correct/couple/pair/towards/at/for/to face/opposite/to treat (sb a certain way)/to match together/to adjust/to fit/to suit/to answer/to reply/classifier: couple

sentences.english: We might even see-saw between both counterproductive poles.
sentences.chinese: 我們甚至可能看到雙方針鋒相對的情況。

sentences.english: What better way to hurt them than with the subversive idea of freedom?
sentences.chinese: 有什麼能夠比針鋒相對的自由思想更能刺痛他們呢？

sentences.english: Two people constantly, the emperor heard great anger, ask less swim.
sentences.chinese: 二人不斷針鋒相對，皇上聽到大怒，問少遊意見。

sentences.english: and we had similar teams that we cheered for, we were also rivals.
sentences.chinese: 我們喜歡同樣的球隊，我們也有針鋒相對的時候。

sentences.english: But as lawmakers took out their pitchforks, Gates responded in kind.
sentences.chinese: 儘管立法者針鋒相對，蓋茨的反應卻很溫和。

sentences.english: A lot of the dialog seems to be combative.
sentences.chinese: 很多的的對話都好像挺針鋒相對的。

definition: to turn a blind eye to
could happen at any moment/on the verge
political relations
to contend on strong grounds/to argue strongly for what is right
unification and independence
to deceive/to conceal
to rope in/fig. to involve sb/to entice
misconception/fallacy
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
to incite trouble/to stir up havoc
use both carrot and stick/use gentle methods and force/an iron hand in a velvet glove
to remain unmoved
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
(of a pendulum) to stop swinging/(of work, production, activities etc) to come to a halt/to be suspended/to be canceled/shutdown/(sports) lockout
lit. severe floods and fierce beasts (idiom)/fig. great scourges/extremely dangerous or threatening things
(Tw) to buy off influential people (in an election, a call for tenders etc)
